subject: Law
title: Smart Contracts and Blockchain
description: A short lesson to help you apply Smart Contracts and Blockchain.

hook.text: A contract executes itself: payment releases automatically when goods arrive. No lawyers needed. Or so they say.

buildup.text: Smart contracts are self-executing code on a blockchain that automatically enforces agreed terms.

discovery.text: They eliminate intermediaries: escrow, banks, and even some legal processes become unnecessary.

twist.text: But code has bugs. The 2016 DAO hack exploited a smart contract flaw, draining $60 million in cryptocurrency.

climax.text: Legal systems are struggling to classify smart contracts. Are they contracts? Software? Something entirely new?

punchline.text: Code can execute a deal. Only law can make it fair.
